conclusion: For the latch to enter the self-locking (no-slip) condition, the component of the spring force that tends to make the latch slide back up the inclined face must be no larger than the maximum static-friction force that can be developed on that face.

Let k – spring stiffness, x – spring compression when self-locking just occurs, θ – inclination of the latch face (given 30°), μ – coefficient of static friction on the contact face, FN – normal force between the latch face and the groove at point P, Fs – spring force = k x.

premise: Force equilibrium along the inclined face.
conclusion: Component of spring force normal to the face: Fs sin θ.

premise: Force equilibrium along the inclined face.
conclusion: Component of spring force tangential to the face (trying to slide the latch up): Fs cos θ.

premise: At the verge of self-locking, Fs cos θ ≤ μ FN.
From the normal equilibrium, FN = Fs sin θ.
Substitute (2) in (1): Fs cos θ ≤ μ (Fs sin θ).
Self-locking occurs only if μ ≥ cot θ.
conclusion: At the instant of self-locking the limiting case is μ = cot θ, and the equalities in (1)–(2) hold.

premise: Numeric substitution: with θ = 30°, sin θ = 0.5.
Self-locking condition and force equilibrium equations.
conclusion: The magnitude of the normal force between the latch D and groove E is FN = k x sin θ.
